description.narrative: Sverige stödjer OECDs "Sector Competitiveness Strategy for Ukraine", sedan 2009. En av policy rekommendationerna inom jordbrukssektorn som OECD föreslagit är att Ukraina bör upprätta ett kreditgarantisystem inom jordbruket för att öka utlåningen och investeringar för små och medelstora jordbruksföretag. Detta projekt på två år syftar till att undersöka möjligheterna att utveckla ett kreditgarantisystem.

Sweden is supporting the OECD "Sector Competitiveness Strategy for Ukraine", 2009 -2015. Key sectors are agribusiness, machinery and transport equipment manufacturing, renewable and energy-efficiency technologies sectors. As a complement to the above, Sida is proposed to support a Credit Guarantee Scheme for Small and Medium Enterprises in agribusiness (2013-2015).

The overall objective of the Action is to enhance access to finance for Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in Ukraine’s agribusiness sector. Building on Phase II of the project “Sector Competitiveness Strategy for Ukraine”, the objective of the Action is to put in place the conditions for establishing a CGS which would initially focus on agricultural SMEs.

participating-org.narrative: OECD Development Centre/Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Unfortunately the guarantee concept that was developed by OECD was contingent on a grant seed funding that would bee leveraged through a guarantee. This mean that Sida was unable to make use of the concept as Sida does not provide guarantee funding. It is unclear as to why Sida's particular approach to using guarantees was not taken into account during the project and why consideration was not given to Sida's involvement in any future guarantee. The concept was however taken by the responsible project manager at the National Bank of Ukraine (NBU) who then implemented it as part of the German Ukrainian Fund's portfolio of instruments aimed at agricultural SMEs. The fund was able to make 18MEURO availbale for SMEs. While the Swedish contribution acknowledged informally no citation or mention of the Swedish engagement was made in further work by the GUF. Discussions with KfW and GIZ were not productive as no further support from Sweden was envisaged in these activities. As of 2020 the German Ukrainian Fund became an agency under the Ministry of Economy when the German partners left the initiative and the guarantee is now an instrument provided by the Ukrainian government. As such the contribution produced quite a substantial impact, just not one that Sweden has any formal association with nor has it led to any visibility for Sweden. This is most likely due to the fact that the concept finalised in the handover period between two programme officers.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
